text:
Bibiana Campos Seijo: We want to bring C&EN
to the 21st century and I think the print
redesign is the first step towards that.

Kevin Davies: It's not just an aesthetic,
cosmetic makeover. It's a fundamental, functional
reimagination of the magazine.

Robert Bryson: We wanted a new design that
would be able to open up the pages, be

more flexible to some of the new things we
want to try. Right now, there's content that's

strewn throughout C&EN that we're pulling
together into the front of the book in a much
more cohesive way.

Matt Davenport: It was just very structured
and regimented and I think what readers will

see is it's a little less of, I don't want
to say it's an unstructured reading experience,

but it's--it feels more open and more inviting,
I think.

Davies: We've listened to what our readers
have said, what they really like about the

publication and we've been able to address
those points and those ideas with this redesign.

Lauren Wolf: It's not even just about the
written words on page. It's about looking
at the art that goes with each piece.

Amanda Yarnell: We're giving our art team,
our creative team, and our reporters a lot

of room in the new design to really make that
as engaging as possible, to make the design
reflect the great storytelling.

Davies: The items that really give the reader
that comprehensive, invaluable summary of

everything that's going on in chemistry around
the world that week, that's now front and

center in the publication. Then they can find
and logically move to the more in-depth and longer

form journalism. Then they can also easily
find the ACS news that gives them a sense

of what the world's largest scientific society
is up to.

Yarnell: It's fresher. It's cleaner. And it's
easier to navigate.
Campos Seijo: Modern, dynamic, very appealing.

Davies: I'm really pleased that our creative
director, Rob Bryson, has taken the reins

and produced an absolutely spectacular redesign
that I think our readers and advertisers are
really going to like.
